data.title: Marty Feldman: The Biography of a Comedy Legend by Robert Ross
data.meta_description: It’s hard to know if Marty Feldman was unlucky, self-destructive or both. Probably both. The man wrote the only sketch anyone shows when discussing British satire in the 1960s — the class sketch with
data.text: It’s hard to know if Marty Feldman was unlucky, self-destructive or both. Probably both. The man wrote the only sketch anyone shows when discussing British satire in the 1960s — the class sketch with John Cleese, Ronnie Barker and Ronnie Corbett, which still finds its way into Channel 4’s 50 greatest comedy sketches despite first going out in 1966. Few people know it was him. He co-authored the four Yorkshiremen grumbling about the violence of their upbringing — in fact, it was written for his early television outing At Last the 1948 Show — but everyone thinks it’s the work of Monty Python. He had his own sketch show on American television, appeared with Dean Martin, Gene Wilder and the Muppets, lived in Hollywood and
